com.markgrand.smileyvars

Class SmileyVarsTemplate

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.markgrand.smileyvars.SmileyVarsTemplate

  • public class SmileyVarsTemplate
extends Object

    SmileyVars is a lightweight template engine for SQL. It helps you avoid having to write similar SQL many times because simple variations are needed.

    The SmileyVars template language is documented at https://mgrand.github.io/smileyVars/.

    This class expands SmileyVars templates into a String that can be used with anything that consumes SQL as Strings. There is a related class, SmileyVarsPreparedStatement, that uses SmileyVars templates with prepared statements. To decide which class you want to use keep these things in mind:

    • If you want to work with SQL statements, SmileyVarsTemplate is the one to use. If you want to work with prepared statements, use SmileyVarsPreparedStatement.
    • SmileyVarsTemplate can infer the SQL type of the values you provide or you can explicitly include the type of a variable in the template body. SmileyVarsPreparedStatement requires you to use methods named for Java types to specify values.
    • If you are working with large blobs or clobs, SmileyVarsPreparedStatement may perform better. It allows you to specify large blob or clob values using write methods that send the value directly to the database without having to represent it as an SQL literal.
    Author:
    Mark Grand
    See Also:
    SmileyVarsPreparedStatement

      • ansiTemplate

        @Deprecated
 @NotNull
public static @NotNull SmileyVarsTemplate ansiTemplate(@NotNull
                                                                               @NotNull String sql)
        Deprecated. Use SmileyVarsTemplate.template(DatabaseType.ANSI, sql)

        Create a template for ANSI-compliant SQL. ANSI SQL is a standard that all relational databases conform to to some extent. This type of template is best when you are planning to write SQL that is portable between different database engines or if you are working with a relational database for which there is no specific template creation method.

        ANSI templates ignore any smileyVars that are inside of string literals, quoted identifiers or comments. Note that ANSI templates recognize nested comments like this:

        /* This is /* all one */ big comment */
        Parameters:
        sql - The template body.
        Returns:
        the template.

      • postgresqlTemplate

        @NotNull
 @Deprecated
public static @NotNull SmileyVarsTemplate postgresqlTemplate(String sql)
        Deprecated. Use SmileyVarsTemplate.template(DatabaseType.POSTGRESQL, sql)
        Create a template for PostgreSQL SQL. This includes support for boolean smileyVars values. It is also able to parse dollar sign delimited string literals and escaped string literals.
        Parameters:
        sql - The template body.
        Returns:
        the template.

      • oracleTemplate

        @NotNull
 @Deprecated
public static @NotNull SmileyVarsTemplate oracleTemplate(String sql)
        Deprecated. Use SmileyVarsTemplate.template(DatabaseType.ORACLE, sql)
        Create a template for Oracle SQL. This is able to parse Oracle delimited string literals. Like Oracle, it does not recognize nested comments.
        Parameters:
        sql - The template body.
        Returns:
        the template.

      • sqlServerTemplate

        @NotNull
 @Deprecated
public static @NotNull SmileyVarsTemplate sqlServerTemplate(String sql)
        Deprecated. Use SmileyVarsTemplate.template(DatabaseType.SQL_SERVER, sql)
        Create a template for Transact SQL (SQL Server). Like SqlServer, it recognizes identifiers that are quoted with square brackets.
        Parameters:
        sql - The template body.
        Returns:
        the template.
